title: Test Doubles üé≠
ques: What is the generic term for any object that replaces a real production object for testing purposes (like a stunt double)?
explanation: Spies, stubs, mocks, and fakes are all types of Test Doubles.

title: Stubs ü™µ
ques: Which type of test double provides canned answers to calls made during the test, usually not responding to anything outside what's programmed?
explanation: Stubs satisfy the dependency's interface with hardcoded responses so your test can proceed.

title: Mocks ü§ñ
ques: Which type of test double is pre-programmed with expectations which form a specification of the calls they are expected to receive?
explanation: Mocks verify *content* (what was passed) and *behavior* (how many times it was called).

title: Spies üïµÔ∏è
ques: Which test double wraps a real object (or function) and records usage information like arguments called, but still executes the real code?
explanation: Spies are useful when you want to verify side effects of a function call without replacing its implementation.

title: Why Mock? ü§∑
ques: What is the main reason to mock a database connection in a unit test?
explanation: Real database calls are slow and require setup/teardown. Mocks are instant and ensure the test only fails if the *unit* logic is broken.
